Award.AwardTitle: 2019 Aspiring Computer Systems Research (CSR) Principal Investigators (PIs) Workshop

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
The goal of this project is to organize the 2019 Computing Systems Research (CSR) Aspiring Investigator workshop. The workshop will bring together aspiring CSR investigators with the goal of familiarizing them with the scope and scale of CSR activities, the process of putting together compelling projects, suitably describing their research, development, education, and outreach goals, and focus on reproducibility and sustained impact. The workshop will also familiarize attendees with crosscutting programs with major CSR components.

The workshop attendees will be drawn from diverse backgrounds, including those from Historically Black Colleges and Universities (HBCU), Minority Educational Institutions (MEI) and other underrepresented groups. The workshop is scheduled for June 20-21, 2019, at the National Science Foundation (NSF) Headquarters in Virginia. The workshop program will include presentations by NSF personnel on various CSR programs/ solicitations, successful CSR investigators on the process of putting together compelling proposals, and a session on the NSF panel review process. Workshop attendees also have open time for questions with the CSR program staff.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The 2019 NSF Aspiring Computer Systems Research Principal Investigators workshop was organized at NSF on June 20, 21, 2019. The workshop was attended by over 40 researchers, senior faculty, and NSF program directors. The workshop familiarized aspiring investigators with various programs at NSF, procedures and policies for NSF proposals, best practices in developing and presenting research ideas, developing strong broader impact and education plans, and intellectual property and commercialization opportunities. Aspiring investigators also heard from accomplished researchers in the field on various aspects of building and sustaining successful research and education careers. An important part of the workshop was individual meetings with NSF program directors, and an opportunity to discuss their research programs in a one-on-one setting. Finally, the workshop also provided a forum for aspiring investigators to present their research programs to peers, with the goal of developing a community of aspiring investigators. Workshop attendees were also able to witness a mock panel, in which real proposals were discussed and categorized -- much the same way a real panel would do.

With respect to broader impact and education, the workshop included presentations by Dr. Payton, who highlighted the need for diversity, and the elements of a strong diversity and outreach component in proposals. With respect to commercialization, Dr. McCauley described the iCorp program, and the opportunities available to computer systems researchers in commercialization. Dr. Golubchik presented findings from her study on findings from women in the CSR program.
